title: Second Nigerian Republic
text:
The Second Nigerian Republic was a brief formation of the Nigerian state which succeeded the military governments formed after the overthrow of the first republic.
Background.
Contested elections and political turbulence in the Western region ended <a href="First%20Nigerian%20Republic">Nigeria's First republic</a> in 1966 with the overthrow of the government by majors of the Nigerian army. A unitary style of government was subsequently decreed into law. After a counter-coup six months later, the country was drawn to a <a href="Biafran%20War">civil war</a> between federal forces and Biafran forces (Eastern region). Just before the war, 12 new states were created from the four regions. After the victory of federal forces in 1970, the country began a period of economic boom fueled by increasing oil production and rising oil prices. The Nigerian governing structure was further broken up with the creation of smaller states in 1976, bringing the total number of states to 19.
Founded (1979).
Following the assassination of Nigerian military Head of State, General <a href="Murtala%20Mohammed">Murtala Mohammed</a> in 1976, his successor General <a href="Olusegun%20Obasanjo">Olusegun Obasanjo</a> initiated the transition process to terminate military rule in 1979. A new <a href="Constitution%20of%20Nigeria">constitution</a> was drafted, which saw the <a href="Westminster%20system">Westminster system</a> of government (previously used in the <a href="Nigerian%20First%20Republic">First Republic</a>) jettisoned for an <a href="United%20States">American</a>-style <a href="Presidential%20system">Presidential system</a>. The 1979 constitution mandated that political parties and <a href="Federal%20Executive%20Council%20%28Nigeria%29">cabinet</a> positions reflect the "federal character" of the nation — Political parties were required to be registered in at least two-thirds of the <a href="States%20of%20Nigeria">states</a>, and each state was required to produce at least one cabinet member.
A <a href="Constituent%20Assembly">constituent assembly</a> was elected in 1977 to draft a new constitution, which was published on September 21, 1978, when the ban on political activity was lifted. In 1979, five political parties competed in a series of elections in which Alhaji <a href="Shehu%20Shagari">Shehu Shagari</a> of the <a href="National%20Party%20of%20Nigeria">National Party of Nigeria</a> (NPN) was elected president. Obasanjo <a href="peacefully%20transferred%20power">peacefully transferred power</a> to Shagari, becoming the first head of state in Nigerian history to willingly step down. All five parties won representation in the National Assembly. In August 1983 Shagari and the NPN were returned to power in a landslide victory, with a majority of seats in the National Assembly and control of 12 state governments. But the elections were marred by violence and allegations of widespread vote rigging and electoral malfeasance led to legal battles over the results.
In the widely monitored 1979 election, <a href="Shehu%20Shagari">Alhaji Shehu Shagari</a> was elected on the NPN platform. On October 1, 1979, Shehu Shagari was sworn in as the first <a href="President%20of%20Nigeria">President and Commander-in-Chief</a> of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. The military carefully planned the return to civil rule putting in place measures to ensure that political parties have broader support than witnessed during the first republic. But there was also uncertainties, like the first republic, political leaders may be unable to govern properly bringing another batch of new military rulers.
Political activism.
<a href="Tai%20Solarin">Tai Solarin</a>, an educationist, mounted public podiums regularly to speak-out in defiance of what he strongly felt were the negative views of the Second Republic government. Another such activist was <a href="Ayodele%20Awojobi">Ayodele Awojobi</a>, a professor of Mechanical Engineering, who filed several lawsuits and organised political rallies in protest of the Nigerian election results that returned <a href="Shehu%20Shagari">Shehu Shagari</a>, the incumbent, as president in the Second Republic - he strongly believed the results were widely rigged.
Overthrow.
On December 31, 1983, the military overthrew the Second Republic. Major General <a href="Muhammadu%20Buhari">Muhammadu Buhari</a>, became the military leader of the new government, citing charges of corruption and administrative incompetence as reasons for <a href="Military%20of%20Nigeria">military</a> intervention. Buhari emerged as the leader of the Supreme Military Council (SMC), the country's new ruling body. President Shagari was placed under <a href="house%20arrest">house arrest</a>, and several of his cabinet members were either jailed or exiled. The Buhari government was peacefully overthrown by the SMC's third-ranking member General <a href="Ibrahim%20Babangida">Ibrahim Babangida</a> in August 1985. Babangida gave misuse of power, violations of human rights by key officers of the SMC, and the government's failure to deal with the country's deepening economic crisis as justifications for the takeover. During his first days in office, President Babangida moved to restore <a href="freedom%20of%20the%20press">freedom of the press</a> and to release political detainees being held without charge. As part of a 15-month economic emergency plan he announced pay cuts for the military, police, civil servants and the private sector. President Babangida demonstrated his intent to encourage public participation in decision-making by opening a national debate on proposed <a href="economic%20reform">economic reform</a> and recovery measures. The public response convinced Babangida of intense opposition to an economic recovery package dependent on an <a href="International%20Monetary%20Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF) loan.
